title: 113_s274
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act". The Act, also known as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act", defines terms related to education and nutrition programs for students to promote healthy eating habits. This includes increasing students' ability to choose healthy foods, understanding influences on healthy eating, and providing education for making healthy eating decisions. The "Children Eating Well Act" aims to provide education for students to make healthy eating decisions as adults, using scientifically sound and developmentally appropriate nutritional materials supported by the Dietary Guidelines for Americans. It includes professional development programs. The "Children Eating Well Act" includes professional development programs for teachers, school staff, and food service workers to promote healthy eating and nutrition education. The "Children Eating Well Act" includes programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education. Local educational agencies receiving assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, including integrating these programs throughout the school day and using educational materials to emphasize healthy eating. The educational programs funded under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 should focus on promoting healthy eating habits among students. This includes emphasizing knowledge of healthy foods, balanced diet and lifestyle, integrating healthy eating with physical activity, and providing various activities to improve student skills related to nutrition without focusing on child weight. Local educational agencies should consult multiple viewpoints in developing programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education, including working with organizations with nutrition education expertise. The Secretary of Education, Secretary of Agriculture, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a task force to review nutrition education curricula and recommend programs for schools. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
